poem:
Title: North, to the Sea's Gloom

In the weary north
brotherly love is woven 
with drug-fuelled despair.
The jackdaw cries

Steel tartarean tarnishes,
war memories mottled
with motocross dust -
he returns, under
smogged sun.

A parcel, sea-skimmed,
cradled in danger's hand -
friendship forgotten
in the mad dance of Silas.

In teetering Tees,
brother minds brother,
the mother is no more -
the jackdaw's song
a mournful score.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Jackdaw review – a tiresome ride through Tees Valley’s drug-fuelled underworld A former motocross champion and army veteran, Jack (Oliver Jackson-Cohen), returns to his home in the industrial north-east of England to care for his younger brother, who has learning disabilities, following the death of their mother. To earn a quick buck, he agrees to a risky North Sea pickup of a mysterious parcel for a former friend turned rave maniac, crime kingpin Silas (Joe". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
